attributes.title: 2020 Negotiation ideology
attributes.description: This study intends to examine how culture (i.e., US and China) affects people's ideology of negotiation and hence their negotiation behaviors. In other words, we want to test if how American and Chinese approach the word "negotiation" is culturally different.

q2.value:
H1: Group ideology of negotiation will generate more competitive strategies.

H2a: Perceived power will mediate the effect of group ideology on competitive strategies.

H2b: Perceived accountability will mediate the effect of group ideology on competitive strategies.

H3: There is an interaction effect between culture (i.e. American and Chinese) and ideology (i.e., group and solo) on competitive strategies, such that the positive effect of group ideology on competitive strategies will be stronger for Chinese rather than Americans.

H4: Chinese rather than Americans will be more likely to have the group ideology regarding the word “negotiation.”

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: 2 (culture: U.S. versus China) by 2 (picture: group versus solo) between-subject design.

q7.value: We will use simple randomization with each of the two cultures. That is to say, each American or Chinese will be randomly assigned into either group condition or solo condition.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: American participants will be recruited through Mturk. Chinese participants will be recruited through the parallel Chinese platform WJX.cn. They will be paid around $ 0.5 for their voluntary participation.

q11.value: Our target sample size is 196 participants. But based on our experience with Mturk and WJX.cn, around 20% of participants will not complete the total task or complete it with valid answers, so we plan to collect a sample size up to 240 participants.

q12.value: We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .95 power to detect a medium effect size of d = 0.52 (based on a previous empirical study on the competitive aspiration difference between American and Chinese in negotiation) at the standard .05 alpha error probability.

question.value: We manipulated the negotiation ideology into two conditions: group ideology or solo ideology, by showing two different pictures (see attached files).

Perceived power

1.	As this negotiator, I am powerful.
2.	As this negotiator, I am in control. 
3.	As this negotiator, I am strong.
4.	As this negotiator, I am confident. 

1. 作为这位谈判者，我觉得很有权势、有影响力。
2. 作为这位谈判者，我感觉一切尽在掌握之中。
3. 作为这位谈判者，我觉得很强势。
4. 作为这位谈判者，我很有自信。

Adopted from: Schaerer, M., Swaab, R. I., & Galinsky, A. D. (2015). Anchors weigh more than power: Why absolute powerlessness liberates negotiators to achieve better outcomes. Psychological science, 26(2), 170-181.


Perceived accountability:

1. I would have very much responsibility for the outcome of this decision.
2. I would feel concerned about the possibility of making a poor choice.
3. This negotiation decision is very important to me.
4. This negotiation decision has an impact on me.

1. 我对做出的决定的结果负有很大责任。
2. 我非常担心在谈判桌上做出错误的决策。
3. 这场谈判的决策对我来说很重要。
4. 这场谈判的决策会对我产生很大的影响。

Adopted from: Zhang, Y., & Mittal, V. (2005). Decision difficulty: Effects of procedural and outcome accountability. Journal of Consumer Research, 32(3), 465-472. 


Competitive strategies:

1. I will push my own point of view.
2. I will search for gains. 
3. I will fight for a good outcome for myself
4. I will do everything to win.

1. 我会努力推销自己的观点。
2. 我会为自己寻求利益。
3. 我会力争自己所需。
4. 我会尽一切努力去争取胜利。


Cooperative strategies (reversed measures of competitive strategies):

1. I will examine issues until I find a solution that really satisfies me and the other party.
2. I will stand for my own and other's goals and interests.
3. I will examine ideas from both sides to find a mutually optimal solution.
4. I will work out a solution that serves my own as well as other's interests as good as possible.

1. 我会研究各个要谈的事项，直到找到能够真正使我和谈判对手都满意的解决方案。
2. 我会维护我自己和谈判对手的目标和利益。
3. 我会研究双方的想法、以找到一个对双方都最佳的解决方案
4. 我会找出出一个解决方案，尽可能服务于自己和谈判对手的利益。

Adopted from: De Dreu, C. K., Evers, A., Beersma, B., Kluwer, E. S., & Nauta, A. (2001). A theory‐based measure of conflict management strategies in the workplace. Journal of Organizational Behavior, 22(6), 645-668.
We will use a two-way ANOVA with both factors between subjects to analyze our results. We will also use the mediation test based on Hayes's Process Model to test the mediation effects.

attributes.title: Intrusive memories following a computerised task
attributes.description: The current study aims to investigate whether utilising visuospatial tasks after exposure to a potentially distressing event can assist in reducing intrusion frequency and intensity over a 1-week period. In particular, this research aims to compare the efficacy of two visuospatial tasks (Tetris and a DCorsi tapping task)

summary.value:
This registration was created after completion of the first paper arising from the project (Paper 1): "Do cognitive tasks reduce intrusive memory frequency after exposure to analogue trauma? An experimental replication" - but prior to the paper's publication.

This registration includes the cognitive task and participant instructions, the de-identified data file (i.e., Spreadsheet_Deidentified_N107.csv) and notes regarding the analyses related to this paper (at https://osf.io/vutcw/). 

Subsequent papers arising from the study pre-registration (https://osf.io/snp8g) will be "forks" from the OSF project.

attributes.title: Enhancing the Sorting Role of Promotions: The Effect of Learning Responsibility
attributes.description: Although promotions have both an incentive purpose and a sorting purpose, the use of promotions for sorting purposes can be challenging for firms. In this study, we examine how varying the training tied to the promotion position promotes the sorting of employees into higher-level positions.

q1.value: The Sorting Role of Promotions and Learning Responsibility

q3.value: Although promotions have both an incentive purpose and a sorting purpose, the use of promotions for sorting purposes can be challenging for firms. In this study, we examine how varying the training tied to the promotion position promotes sorting of employees into higher-level positions. Building on theories about learning, we predict that the difference in promotion desirability between employees whose current skills match versus not match the skills required in the promotion position is larger when the training tied to the position requires more learning responsibility from the employee. We aim to contribute to the promotion literature by examining how the different types of training can be used to enhance the sorting role of promotions.

q4.value: The difference in promotion desirability between employees whose current skills match versus not match the skills in the higher-level promotion position is larger for high-responsibility types of training than low-responsibility types of training.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Between subjects design where we manipulate whether there is a match between the skills of 
the employee and the skills required in the promotion position (match versus no match) and the degree of responsibility for learning the required skills during the training tied to the promotion position (low versus high).

q9.value: We will randomly allocate participants to one of the four treatment groups.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will recruit participants from a pool of Master and MBA students at a European business school by sending out an invitation. Participation is voluntary because participants can decide whether they will participate.

q13.value: Our target sample size is around 120 participants. We are aiming at at least 30 participants per treatment group.

question.value: We independently manipulate (a) whether employees’ skills required in the current position and on the higher-level position match or do not match and (b) the degree of responsibility for learning the required skills during the training tied to the promotion position (low versus high).
Our primary dependent variable is the employees' desire to be promoted ("promotion desirability"). We measure it on a scale from 0 to 100.
To test our hypothesis, we will use regression analysis. That is, we will predict employees' promotion desirability as a function of the two between-subjects factors and their interaction.

q24.value: We expect that certain demographics and personality traits may be related to promotion desirability. Therefore, we will look for those relationships.

attributes.title: Effectiveness of acupuncture and electro-acupuncture for lateral elbow tendinopathy
attributes.description: Epicondylalgia, also known as epicondylitis, epicondylosis, lateral elbow pain, lateral elbow tendinopathy or tennis elbow, is a common upper arm painful condition. Epicondylalgia is pain in the lateral epicondyle of the humerus or in the tendons or muscles originating from it. The condition usually arises from resisted use of the extensor muscles of the wrist and can be associated with occupational tasks or sports  which require forceful and/or repetitive activity. Overall the economic burden of epicondylalgia is high resulting in significant loss of work days and reduced work capacity.

q2.value: Acupuncture or electro-acupuncture (realized on Traditional Chinese Medicine Points) are effective for the treatment of the lateral elbow tendinopathy

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: A systematic review and meta-analysis included parallel or cross-over randomized clinical trials that used  acupuncture o electro-acupuncture alone or in combination with other treatments in comparison with other group or control

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Inclusion criteria: Participants must be al least 18 years old with lateral elbow tendinopathy treated with acupuncture needle intervention (acupuncture or electro-acupuncture) using Traditional Chinese Medicine approach. Also, the included studies will be randomized clinical trials with at least one group that used a needle intervention (acupuncture o electro-acupuncture) alone or in combination with other therapy and a comparative group (other intervention or control group).

Exclusion criteria: inadequate control group for comparison, needle intervention with drug (e.g drug injection), dry needling or acupuncture using a  Myofascial Trigger Point approach, written studies not English or Spanish language, lateral elbow pain from non-musculoskeletal origin

q11.value: We will analyze all studies that we can include in the systematic review and meta-analysis

question.value: Efficacy outcomes like intensity of pain (for example numeric rating scale of pain or visual analogue scale), function/disability (for example PRTEE questionnaire or DASH questionnaire) or/and hand-grip strength (for example maximal voluntary contraction of hand-drip or free pain hand grip strength)

We will use Review Manager 5.3 software to statistically analyze data. If there is homogeneity between the studies we will use a fixed effect model, otherwise, a random effects model will be applied.

Heterogeneity and inconsistency will be assessed through the inspection of a forest plot, and I² test, and based on the criteria of each study.

Furthermore we will use the funnel plot to check the potential publication bias.

If we have sufficient data, we will conduct subgroup analyses according to the mean period of follow-up and needle interventions.

q23.value:
Two independent authors will screen both the titles and abstracts of the references retrieved during the searches, after which full text screening will be carried out in accordance with the inclusion and exclusion criteria.

Data extraction will also be carried out by two independent authors, and data including title, author, published date, study design, and other data concerning our research questions will be collected. For all steps, any disagreements will be resolved by a third author, if required.

The risk of bias assessment will be carried out by two or more authors in accordance with the recommendations set out in the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions, including following items: sequence generation, allocation concealment, blinding of participants, personnel and outcome assessors, incomplete outcome data, selective outcome reporting, and other sources of bias. We will grade each item as “low risk”, “high risk”, or “unclear”. Disagreements will be discussed with another reviewer. Also the PEDro score was performed to evaluate the metohodological quality

attributes.title: Sport motives and life satisfaction
attributes.description: A study to investigate the link between sport motives and life satisfaction in athletes. We aim to replicate results found by Jetzke and Mutz (2019) that demonstrated how different sport motives differ in their effect on life satisfaction. In a second, exploratory analysis, we examine  if different sport motives can be described by different regulatory styles of motivation (Self-Determination Theory).

q1.value: Manuel Rein, Sophia Terwiel, Stephen Lee Murphy

q2.value:
Hypothesis 1:
Athlete’s life satisfaction is affected by their sport motives.
- The (rather) controlled sport motives Body/Appearance, Competition/Performance, Distraction/Catharsis, and Health are associated with lower well-being.
- The (rather) autonomous motives Contact, Aesthetics, and Fitness are associated with higher well-being.

Hypothesis 2:
Sport motives can be described by SDT’s regulatory styles:
- intrinsic regulation: Aesthetics
- integrated regulation: Contact, Fitness
- identified regulation: Health, Competition/Performance
- Introjected regulation: Body/Appearance, Distraction/Catharsis

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Observational, cross-sectional study. A survey will be provided online via Qualtrics Survey Tool (Qualtrics, 2020).
o Estimated duration: 20-25 minutes
o Survey language: English

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
- Participants need to be at least 18 years old and practice sport regularly: in line with the original study (Jetzke & Mutz, 2019), participants need to have practiced at least once a week for at least the last 6 months to be included.
- Exclusion criteria: incorrect answer to instructed-response items or quality item
- Participants will be recruited via social media (Facebook, Instagram, Reddit) and/or personal contacts.
- We will use Cook’s distance (Cook, 1977) to identify influential data points in the linear regression model, using 4/n as cutoff.

q11.value: - In the study conducted by Jetzke and Mutz (2019), including the sport motives in a linear regression model increased R² significantly by .024. In order to find an effect of this size with a power of .80 at .05 alpha error probability, at least 600 participants need to be recruited.

q12.value:
Calculated using the package pwr in R (Stephane Champely, 2018):
> pwr.f2.test(u = 7, f2 = .024, sig.level = .05, power = .8)

q13.value: - Active recruiting will end when 600 participants have finished the survey. The survey will close at April 30, 2020.

question.value:
Demographic data
-	Age (in years)
-	Gender
-	Relationship status
-	Education (in years and highest level)
-	Country

Sport questions:
-	Sport mainly practiced
-	Other sport practiced
-	For how long the participant has practiced his or her main sport
-	On which level the participant performs his or her main sport
-	How often (per week) the participant practices his or her main sport currently
-	How many hours (per week) the participant spends practicing his or her main sport currently

Other information
-	Three instructed response items and one item to assess data quality
-	Big Five Personality traits (BFI 2-S; Soto & John, 2017)

Sport motives, sport motivation, life satisfaction
-	Bernese motive and goal inventory (BMZI; Schmid et al., 2018)
-	Satisfaction with Life Scale (SWLS; Diener et al., 1985)
-	Revised Sport Motivation Scale (SMS-II; Pelletier et al., 2013)

All analyses will be performed in R (R Core Team, 2020), using RStudio (RStudio Team, 2018).

Hypothesis 1 (confirmatory)
Multiple linear regression model comparison
- Model 1 (Control variables):
o Independent variables: age, gender, relationship status
o Dependent variable: Life Satisfaction (SWLS)
- Model 2 (full model):
o Independent variables: Control variables (see Model 1) plus 7 sport motives (Body/Appearance, Contact, Competition/Performance, Aesthetics, Distraction/Catharsis, Fitness, Health (BMZI))
o Dependent variable: Life Satisfaction (SWLS)

Hypothesis 2 (exploratory)
- Each sport motive (Body/Appearance, Contact, Competition/Performance, Aesthetics, Distraction/Catharsis, Fitness, Health; BMZI) will be tested for correlation with each regulatory style of SDT (intrinsic, integrated, identified, introjected, external and amotivated regulation; SMS-II).

q18.value:
The variable Age will be centered.

Sport motives (BMZI):
Jetzke and Mutz (2019) mean-centered the sport motives scores for each respondent: the mean score of all 7 motives was calculated, then that mean was subtracted from that person’s value for each motive. As a result, each motive value indicates how strong the motive is relative to other motives of the same person. To make our results comparable to the original study, we will use the same procedure for the replication study. However, it should be noted that this prevents analysing sport motives independently of each other.

Life Satisfaction (SWLS):
While Diener et al. (1985) suggest calculating the sum score for the SWLS, the mean score was used in the analysis by Jetzke and Mutz (2019). Therefore, this study will also utilize the mean score.

Sport Motviation (SMS-II):
The mean score for each regulatory style will be calculated.

q19.value: All statistical test will be performed at .05 alpha error probability.

q20.value:
- Participants need to be at least 18 years old and practice sport regularly: in line with the original study (Jetzke & Mutz, 2019), participants need to have practiced at least once a week for at least the last 6 months to be included.
- Exclusion criteria: incorrect answer to instructed-response items or quality item
- We will use Cook’s distance (Cook, 1977) to identify influential data points in the linear regression model, using 4/n as cutoff.

q23.value:
Note regarding the coronavirus pandemic
- The massive impact of COVID-19 on our everyday life will most probably also have an effect on some constructs included in this study. The reason for that is that most people won’t be able to participate in regular sport activities the way they are used to because of  lockdowns in most countries (see Kaplan, Frias, & McFall-Johnsen, 2020). Additionally, participant’s overall well-being might be lower. To take these possible differences into account, we will administer some questionnaires twice.
- Questions on the frequency and duration of sport participation, as well as sport motives (BMZI; Schmid et al., 2018), will be assessed for the current situation as well as retrospectively regarding the time before the coronavirus pandemic, if the participants indicate that their sport participation is affected due to the coronavirus pandemic. 
- The SWLS (Diener et al., 1985) will be assessed two times. First, at the beginning of the survey with regard to the participants’ current life satisfaction. Second, at the end of the survey with regard to participants’ life satisfaction before the corona crisis.
- The instructions for the Revised Sport Motivation Scale (Pelletier, Rocchi, Vallerand, Deci, & Ryan, 2013) have been adapted. Participants are asked to refer to their sport motivation prior to the corona pandemic.
- Questions: 
o Is the participant’s sport participation limited due to the corona pandemic? If yes: How often (per week) did the participant practice their main sport prior to the pandemic? How many hours (per week) did the participant spend practicing their main sport prior to the pandemic?

registration_responses.q1: Manuel Rein, Sophia Terwiel, Stephen Lee Murphy
registration_responses.q2:
Hypothesis 1:
Athlete’s life satisfaction is affected by their sport motives.
- The (rather) controlled sport motives Body/Appearance, Competition/Performance, Distraction/Catharsis, and Health are associated with lower well-being.
- The (rather) autonomous motives Contact, Aesthetics, and Fitness are associated with higher well-being.

Hypothesis 2:
Sport motives can be described by SDT’s regulatory styles:
- intrinsic regulation: Aesthetics
- integrated regulation: Contact, Fitness
- identified regulation: Health, Competition/Performance
- Introjected regulation: Body/Appearance, Distraction/Catharsis

In order to find an effect of this size with a power of .80 at .05 alpha error probability, at least 600 participants need to be recruited.

registration_responses.q18:
The variable Age will be centered.

Sport motives (BMZI):
Jetzke and Mutz (2019) mean-centered the sport motives scores for each respondent: the mean score of all 7 motives was calculated, then that mean was subtracted from that person’s value for each motive. As a result, each motive value indicates how strong the motive is relative to other motives of the same person. To make our results comparable to the original study, we will use the same procedure for the replication study. However, it should be noted that this prevents analysing sport motives independently of each other.

Life Satisfaction (SWLS):
While Diener et al. (1985) suggest calculating the sum score for the SWLS, the mean score was used in the analysis by Jetzke and Mutz (2019). Therefore, this study will also utilize the mean score.

Sport Motviation (SMS-II):
The mean score for each regulatory style will be calculated.
registration_responses.q19: All statistical test will be performed at .05 alpha error probability.

registration_responses.q17.question:
All analyses will be performed in R (R Core Team, 2020), using RStudio (RStudio Team, 2018).

Hypothesis 1 (confirmatory)
Multiple linear regression model comparison
- Model 1 (Control variables):
o Independent variables: age, gender, relationship status
o Dependent variable: Life Satisfaction (SWLS)
- Model 2 (full model):
o Independent variables: Control variables (see Model 1) plus 7 sport motives (Body/Appearance, Contact, Competition/Performance, Aesthetics, Distraction/Catharsis, Fitness, Health (BMZI))
o Dependent variable: Life Satisfaction (SWLS)

Hypothesis 2 (exploratory)
- Each sport motive (Body/Appearance, Contact, Competition/Performance, Aesthetics, Distraction/Catharsis, Fitness, Health; BMZI) will be tested for correlation with each regulatory style of SDT (intrinsic, integrated, identified, introjected, external and amotivated regulation; SMS-II).

attributes.title: Programmatic influences on questionable research practices in final-year psychology dissertations
attributes.description:
Preregistration prepared by Caroline Elliott
In the last decade, there has been an increased focus on Open Science and the reasons behind the nonvalidity and reproducibility of psychological research (Open Science Collaboration, 2015). Gigerenzer (2018) postulates that researchers’ widespread faith in statistical ritual is a contributing factor, and the possibility that the emphasis on statistical significance (via p-values) could alter research design and analysis. These attitudes, held by researchers, can lead to scientific misconduct (Tijdink, Verbeke and Smulders,2014) or at the very least honest errors (Sacco and Brown, 2019). 
This study examines a set of actions that sit within a grey area called Questionable Research Practices (QRP’s), which are often open to interpretation and differing tolerance levels within Higher Education establishments. The variation in student attitudes has been demonstrated to be directly influenced by the attitudes and endorsements of dissertation and thesis supervisors (Krishna and Peters, 2018). 
The aim of the study is to examine the programmatic influences on final year undergraduate students’ perception of QRP’s. The study will conceptually replicate the previous work of Krishna and Peters (2018) with a focus on programmatic influences and not on supervisor attitudes. The questionnaire used is a combination of a replication of Krishna and Peters’ and additional adapted questions to examine programme effects.
The study is a collaboration between 13 University psychology departments, each has contributed a set of questions to a main Qualtrics questionnaire. This main questionnaire is answered in full by all participants, however I have only used data from my own contributed questions. Therefore, I have excluded data from other universities that is not relevant to my research question.
In addition to the student Qualtrics questionnaire I have compiled an additional questionnaire for the programme leaders. It evaluates their perception as to the level of knowledge of QRP’s that psychology graduates would have upon completion of their statistics, methods and analysis programme (based on the inclusion of Open science teaching within their programme). The questionnaire also explored whether Open Science and reproducibility is included in any other modules within the programme.
References 
Gigerenzer, G. (2018) Statistical rituals: The replication delusion and how we got there. Advances in Methods and Practices in Psychological Science, 1 (2), 198-218.
Krishna, A. & Peter, S. (2018) Questionable research practices in student final theses–Prevalence, attitudes, and the role of the supervisor’s perceived attitudes. PloS one, 13 (8).
Open Science Collaboration (2015) PSYCHOLOGY. Estimating the reproducibility of psychological science. Science, 349.
Sacco, D., & Brown, M. (2019) Assessing the efficacy of a training intervention to reduce acceptance of questionable research practices in psychology graduate students. Journal of Empirical Research on Human Research Ethics, 14 (3), 209-218.
Tijdink, J., Verbeke, R., Smulders, Y. (2014) Publication pressure and scientific misconduct in medical scientists. Journal of Empirical Research on Human Research Ethics, 9 (5), 64-71.

q2.value: More positive perceived programmatic attitudes towards QRPs should lead to greater reported QRP use. This effect should be mediated by students’ QRP attitudes.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is an observational cohort study.

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value:
The target participants are undergraduate psychology students from 13 UK universities.
•	University of Bath
•	University of Bristol
•	University of Cambridge
•	Cardiff University
•	University of Dundee
•	University of Edinburgh
•	Goldsmiths University 
•	University of Liverpool
•	Royal Holloway
•	University of St Andrews
•	University of Plymouth
•	University of the West of England
•	University College London

Participants will be final year psychology students undertaking their dissertations, recruited via the standard psychology student recruitment procedures (e.g. participant pool) or advertised locally in modules or programme e-mail lists.
Participation is on a voluntary basis.

q11.value:
The programme leader questionnaire sample size will be 13 if all are completed.
Estimated sample size for the student questionnaire is 1300 participants, assuming 100 students from each of the participating universities completes the questionnaire. End of data collection is not dependent on the number of participants, as all qualifying questionnaires will be used at the specified closing date.

question.value:
1.	Student own perception of QRP use.
Students were asked the extent (from sensible to problematic) that they would view the use of QRP’s in their third-year dissertation/future research?
2.	Student perception of the programme’s perception of QRP’s.
Students were asked the extent (from sensible to problematic) that the lecturers on the statistics and research module viewed QRP’s
3.	Students perception of which QRP’s were taught in the programme. 
Students were asked to identify which QRP’s were taught within their programmes.
4.	Programme leaders reported level of inclusion of QRP teaching. 
Programme leaders were asked to identify which QRP’s are included on their current programme.
5.	Programme leaders’ perception of QRP use. 
Programme leaders were asked to rate a level of confidence (from not confident to very confident) that students are practicing open science within their third-year dissertations.
All predictors are measured using scales specifically generated for this study.
Scales are scored on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 1-Sensible to 5-problematic or 1- very confident to 5- not confident at all. 
Self-report QRPs use is assessed with the item “Which of these terms were taught on your statistics and research methods modules or in any other modules on your course?” with a possible yes/no response.  
Programme QRP inclusion is assessed with the item “Which of these terms are taught on your statistics and research methods modules or in any other module on your programme?” with a possible yes/no response.
  QRP’s evaluated in the study include:
•	Replication crisis 					
•	Open science 				
•	P-Hacking                         				       
•	HARKing (Hypothesising After Results are Known)	 
•	Confirmation bias          				 
•	File Drawer effect           				 
•	Statistical power            				 
•	Publication bias               				 
•	Data sharing                 	 			 
•	Study pre-registration    				 
•	Registered reports 				 
•	Bayesian statistics  
Programme leader questionnaires ask general questions pertaining to the inclusion of Open Science within their programmes, a confidence rating, and the QRP list.
Reference 
Krishna, A. and Peter, S. (2018) Questionable research practices in student final theses–Prevalence, attitudes, and the role of the supervisor’s perceived attitudes. PloS one, 13 (8).

To evaluate the hypothesis, a mediation model will be calculated using the PROCESS macro (Hayes, 2017), which includes participant QRP attitudes, the effect of perceived programme influence (course content) and perceived lecturers views on QRP’s.

attributes.title: PSYC 2017 project
attributes.description: This research study will primarily focus on replicating previous studies to determine the validity and reliability of the unstructured interview. The validity of unstructured interviews has broad implications in society because at any level in the professional world, interviews are constantly occurring. The hiring process can have severe effects on both the employee and the employer if done using methods that enhance subjectivity and overconfidence within the interviewer. Determining the validity of unstructured interviews can help employers implement interviewing procedures and policies that benefit all parties during the interview, rather than relying on individual subjectivity to accurately determine employee productivity, job performance, and training success. Therefore, we will determine the ability of the unstructured interview to predict long-term job productivity and training success. We will measure this through the interviewer's scores of the applicants then compare this to actual productivity of applicants.

q1.value: Effectiveness of Unstructured Interviews on Predicting Performance

q3.value: This research study will primarily focus on replicating previous studies to determine the validity and reliability of the unstructured interview. The validity of unstructured interviews has broad implications in society because at any level in the professional world, interviews are constantly occurring. The hiring process can have severe effects on both the employee and the employer if done using methods that enhance subjectivity and overconfidence within the interviewer. Determining the validity of unstructured interviews can help employers implement interviewing procedures and policies that benefit all parties during the interview, rather than relying on individual subjectivity to accurately determine employee productivity, job performance, and training success. Therefore, we will determine the ability of the unstructured interview to predict long-term job productivity and training success. We will measure this through the interviewer's scores of the applicants then compare this to actual productivity of applicants.

q4.value: If unstructured interviews are used throughout the hiring process, then there will be inaccurate predictions of job performance, employee productivity, and training success. This is a directional hypothesis in that the larger the reliance on unstructured interviews, the higher the risk of inaccurately predicting an applicants job-related skills. It is predicted that there will be an increase in overconfidence and a decrease in ability to accurately predict employee productivity, job performance, and training success if unstructured interviews are used as a primary method of prediction.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

question.value: A between subjects design with three groups being tested. One group goes through an unstructured interview, one goes through a structured interview, and the last goes through an unstructured interview as well as being judged by test scores. The personnel who are analyzing the data will be unaware of what group the subjects are in, so that the subjects can have an even chance of being picked and that their performance will be adequately measured. After the subjects are picked using the 3 different methods, they will be given a low level job and their performance will be measured.

q9.value: We will use block random sampling where each participant will be randomly assigned to one of the three equally sized, predetermined groups. The random number list used to create these three groups will be created using the applications available at https://www.randomizer.org/.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through advertisements on LSU campus and will be offered either class credit or $20 (raised to $40 if sample size is not reached within 20 days of recruitment). Participants must be at least 18 years old and be able to read, write, and think critically. The timeline of this study will be over 3 months. The first month will consist of recruitment, the second month will consist of data collection, and the third month will consist of data analysis.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 200 human participants. We will attempt to recruit up to 250 participants, considering some participants will not complete the task.

question.value: The manipulated variable will be the evaluation process that the subjects go through, whether that be an unstructured interview, structured interview, or the unstructured interview and test scores.

The outcome variable will be the predicted level of productivity, training success, and training success. We will measure this by asking participants to perform a low level job and seeing their success in this.
We will use a between subjects ANOVA test to test our hypothesis, as we have three different groups of individuals that are being evaluated.

Participants must be at least 18 years old and be able to read, write, and think critically. The timeline of this study will be over 3 months. The first month will consist of recruitment, the second month will consist of data collection, and the third month will consist of data analysis.
registration_responses.q16.question: The manipulated variable will be the evaluation process that the subjects go through, whether that be an unstructured interview, structured interview, or the unstructured interview and test scores.
registration_responses.q17.question: The outcome variable will be the predicted level of productivity, training success, and training success. We will measure this by asking participants to perform a low level job and seeing their success in this.
registration_responses.q19.question: We will use a between subjects ANOVA test to test our hypothesis, as we have three different groups of individuals that are being evaluated.

attributes.title: In-class laptop usage
attributes.description: This study will assess students from every year in undergraduate school via survey in order to determine what motivates them to use their portable devices for non-class related activities.

q1.value: Maggie Butler, Cody Capps, Erin Fortier

q2.value: I hypothesize that poor time-management (working on material due for other classes during lecture), boredom (disinterest in lecture material), and impulsivity (lack of self-control in terms of laptop multitasking) are major contributors to why students’ academic performance declines when laptops are used in class. I predict that impulsivity and poor time-management will have greater affects on non-class related device usage.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Online survey to assess interest in lecture material, time management skills, and impulsivity. Surveys will be given to undergraduate college students of every year across different majors.

q7.value: Randomization is not required for this study.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Data will be collected from 16 classrooms in which devices are used. English, psychology, math, and biology majors in courses at every level (1000,2000,3000,4000) will be sent a link to an online survey and teachers will ask their students to take it in class. The data will be available for analysis once the surveys are submitted.

q11.value: There will be 16 classrooms selected to participate. A 1000, 2000, 3000, and 4000 level course from each of four majors (English, psychology, math, and biology). Number of students per classroom will vary.

q12.value: I chose to assess 16 classes because I wanted to include responses from individuals from every year (freshman, sophomore, junior, senior) and from a variety of majors.

q13.value: Data collection will be completed after all 16 classes have completed the survey.

question.value: There will be 3 outcome variables: interest in lecture material, self-perceived time management skills, and self-perceived impulsivity. Participants will respond to statements on a scale from 1-5 with 1 being "strongly disagree" and 5 being "strongly agree". The survey will include statements like "I often check my phone when my teacher is lecturing.", "I use class time to study or do homework for other classes." and "when the lecture material doesn't interest me, I usually find something online to do." There will be 10 statements targeting each variable. (30 statements total)
Statements for each variable will be assessed separately.

Once data is collected, responses to each statement will be attached to their corresponding variable so there will be three different analyses. Data will be obtained through a survey created through Qualtrics, which will automatically generate a report showing the min, max, mean, standard deviation, and variance of the responses to each statement . Using the frequencies of responses on the scale to each statement (combining 1 and 2, leaving 3 separate, and combining 4 and 5), I will be able to calculate the percent of students who feel like they use their laptops for non-class related activities due to impulsivity, poor time-management, or disinterest in lecture material.

q18.value: The study does not require any further transformations.

q19.value: I will be reporting the percentages of students who agreed or disagreed to the statements regarding their impulsivity, interest in lecture material, and time-management.

q20.value: Respondents must select a response to each of the 30 statements for it to be submitted.

q21.value: Surveys taken by participants who do not respond to every statement will not be included in analysis.

q22.value: I suspect that age may be a factor that may affect responses to statements. Therefore, I will examine the relationship between age and responses.

q23.value: Inspiration for this study comes from the article by Ravizza et al.: Logged In and Zoned Out: How Laptop Internet Use Relates to Classroom Learning

attributes.title: Framing effects on the effectiveness and virality of health messages related to COVID-19
attributes.description:
Humor appeals can help draw audiences’ attention, and improve engagement with the information, which is why they are often deployed as a creative alternative to more didactic messaging appeals (Nabi, R. L., Moyer-Gusé, E., and Byrne, S., 2007; Cline, T. W., & Kellaris, J. J., 2007; Blanc, N., & Brigaud, E., 2014). Thus, humorous appeals to persuade individuals to follow COVID-19 related preventative measures may help engage audiences and increase behavior change. Humorous messages, however, can take various forms, including, but not limited to irony, sarcasm, mockery and satire (Holbert et al., 2011; Polk et al., 2009). In the current study, we focus on mocking forms of humor, which can lead to more unfavorable evaluations of the target of the joke (Becker, 2012). By mocking the behavior of individuals who do not follow physical distancing recommendations when they could, we might encourage audiences to follow these recommendations when possible. Here, recognizing that not everyone has the luxury to avoid all contact with others, we manipulate humor in appeals such that these humorous messages ridicule individuals who are not following social distancing recommendations, despite being in positions that afford them the ability to do so. 
Here, we will focus on participants who will be randomly assigned to one of two conditions, as part of a larger study (https://osf.io/8hn2g/) that has 5 total conditions.

In this study, participants will either be exposed to 1) messages framed humorously, or 2) control messages. We test the effects of these messages primarily on (1) perceptions of norms about social distancing, (2) favorability of message (i.e., the extent to which the message makes the person want to follow social distance recommendations), and (3) intention to share the message. We compare the effects of humorous messages, and control messages which are not framed humorously.

References
Becker, A. B. (2012). Comedy types and political campaigns: The differential influence of other-directed hostile humor and self-ridicule on candidate evaluations. Mass Communication and Society, 15(6), 791-812.
Blanc, N., & Brigaud, E. (2014). Humor in print health advertisements: Enhanced attention, privileged recognition, and persuasiveness of preventive messages. Health communication, 29(7), 669-677.
Cline, T. W., & Kellaris, J. J. (2007). The influence of humor strength and humor—message relatedness on ad memorability: A dual process model. Journal of Advertising, 36(1), 55-67.
Holbert, R. L., Hmielowski, J., Jain, P., Lather, J., & Morey, A. (2011). Adding nuance to the study of political humor effects: Experimental research on juvenalian satire versus horatian satire. American Behavioral Scientist, 55(3), 187-211.
Nabi, R. L., Moyer-Gusé, E., and Byrne, S. (2007). All joking aside: A serious investigation into the persuasive effect of funny social issue messages. Communication Monographs, 74(1), 29-54.
Polk, J., Young, D. G., & Holbert, R. L. (2009). Humor complexity and political influence: An elaboration likelihood approach to the effects of humor type in The Daily Show with Jon Stewart. Atlantic Journal of Communication, 17(4), 202-219.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

sample.value: We conducted a small pilot study to assess potential effect sizes and variance parameters. Based on these results, we conducted a power analysis using the PANGEA power calculator (https://jakewestfall.shinyapps.io/pangea/) and determined we would have >80% power to detect an effect size of d = .2 for within- and between-subject effects with N = 200 per experimental condition.

analyses.value:
PRIMARY ANALYSIS
To assess the effect of humorous framing on norms, we will use linear regression, where the control condition will be treated as the reference group. To assess the effect of humorous framing on message favorability and message sharing, we will use multilevel modeling, where the message control condition will be the reference group, such that the fixed effect for each experimental condition will be the mean difference between it and the message control condition. Trials are nested within participant, and participant intercepts and message intercepts will be treated as random. Message ratings will be z-scored across participants. 
> lm(norms_town ~ 1 + condition)
> lmer(favorability ~ 1 + condition + (1|participant ID) + (1|message))
> lmer(sharing ~ 1 + condition + (1|participant ID) + (1|message))

SECONDARY ANALYSIS
To assess the interaction effect between condition and need for cognition on sharing and favorability (as outlined in hypotheses 4-5), we will regress sharing on 1) the main effects of condition and need for cognition, and 2) their interaction.
> lm(favorability ~ 1 + condition*cognition + condition + cognition)
> lm(sharing ~ 1 + condition*cognition + condition + cognition)

To assess the effect of humorous framing on message level outcome measures (as outlined in hypotheses 6-7), we will use multilevel modeling, where the message control condition will be the reference group, such that the fixed effect for each experimental condition will be the mean difference between it and the message control condition. Trials are nested within participant, and participant intercepts and message intercepts will be treated as random. Message ratings will be z-scored across participants. 
> lmer(social relevance ~ 1 + condition + (1|participant ID) + (1|message))
> lmer(self motivation ~ 1 + condition + (1|participant ID) + (1|message))

To assess the effect of humorous framing on person level outcome measures (as outlined in hypotheses 8-10), we will use linear regression, where the control condition will be treated as the reference group.
> lm(norms_close ~ 1 + condition)
> lm(intention ~ 1 + condition)
> lm(social acceptability ~ 1 + condition)

To test whether humor has positive or negative/ unintended consequences in decreasing or increasing prejudice and increasing or decreasing support for policies that support vulnerable individuals (as outlined in RQ1), we will use linear regression, where the control condition will be treated as the reference group. We will explore whether participants in humor vs. control groups express greater prejudice (operationalized as dehumanization) toward any of the groups measured. We will also explore whether participants in humor vs. control groups express differential support for any of the policies described.
> lm(dehumanization ~ 1 + condition)
> lm(policies ~ 1 + condition)

outliers.value:
Participants will be excluded according to the criteria in the standard operating procedures for this project listed on OSF: https://osf.io/8hn2g/.

We will exclude individual responses that are missing from analyses. Outliers that are more than 3 SDs from the mean will be winsorized to +/- 3 SD.

dependent.value:
•	Perceived social norms in respondents’ city or town (measured at individual level; an average of the ratings to the following four questions will be used)
For these questions, think about people in your city or town. What proportion of them will do the following in the next two weeks (0%-100%) 
> Stay home and avoid all social contact, even if they aren’t sick.
> Limit their grocery shopping to once a week or less.
> Stay at least 6 feet apart from others when they’re in public. 
> Avoid all public gatherings, even if they aren’t sick.

•	Perceived social norms among respondents’ close friends and family (measured at individual level; an average of the ratings to the following four questions will be used)
For these questions, think about your closest friends and family. What proportion of them will do the following in the next two weeks(0%-100%) 
> Stay home and avoid all social contact, even if they aren’t sick.
> Limit their grocery shopping to once a week or less.
> Stay at least 6 feet apart from others when they’re in public. 
> Avoid all public gatherings, even if they aren’t sick.

•	Favorability (1 = strongly disagree, 7 = strongly agree) (measured at the message level for each individual; difference between ratings of positive and negative items will be used)
> The message put thoughts in my mind about wanting to avoid physical contact with others (pos)
> The message put thoughts in my mind about not wanting to avoid physical contact with others (neg)

•	Sharing (1 = strongly disagree, 7 = strongly agree) (measured at the message level for each individual)
> I would share this message on social media.

•	Motivation (1 = strongly disagree, 7 = strongly agree) (measured at the message level for each individual)
> The message motivates me to avoid physical contact with others

•	Social relevance (1 = strongly disagree, 7 = strongly agree) (measured at the message level for each individual)
> This message is relevant to other people I know

•	Intentions to engage in COVID-19 preventative behavior (measured at individual level; an average of the ratings to the following four questions will be used)
Please rate how much you intend to do the following things over the next two weeks (1 = definitely won’t, 7 = definitely will)
> Stay home and avoid all social contact, even if I'm not sick 
> Limit my grocery shopping to once a week or less 
> Stay at least 6 feet apart from others when I’m in public 
> Avoid all public gatherings even if I’m not sick

•	Social acceptability of social distancing behavior (measured at individual level; an average of the ratings to the following seven questions will be used)
I think it is socially acceptable for me to (1=strongly disagree, 7=strongly agree)
> Stay home and avoid all social contact, even if I’m not sick
> Go outside and visit restaurants and pubs*
> Limit my grocery shopping to once a week or less
> Plan air travel because flight prices are cheap*
> Stay at least 6 feet apart from others when I’m in public
> Avoid all public gatherings even if I’m not sick
> Invite friends over for get-togethers*
*reverse coded

•	Dehumanization of vulnerable groups (measured at individual level; an average of the ratings to the following seven questions will be used)
Using the image below as a guide, indicate using the sliders how evolved you consider the average member of each group to be. There are no right or wrong answers here: we are simply interested in your opinion.
> Muslim
> Chinese people
> Italian people
> Undocumented immigrants
> Children
> Elderly
> American people
> People with COVID-19 (coronavirus)
> People with weakened immune systems
> Unemployed people

•	Support for public policies related to COVID-19 (measured at individual level; an average of the ratings to the following seven questions will be used)
To what extent do you support the following policies in response to the COVID-19 pandemic? (1 = do not support at all, 7 = support very much)
> Increased funding for Coronavirus research and vaccine development.
> Two weeks of paid sick leave for workers during the COVID-19 pandemic to help those impacted by quarantine orders or those who must stay home to care for children.
> Paid leave of 67% average monthly earnings for unemployment caused by COVID-19.
> Free coronavirus testing (including emergency room visits and doctor fees) for all U.S. citizens and permanent residents.
> Two rounds of direct payment to taxpayers of on average $1000 each.
> Expanded coverage of small business loans for companies with fewer than 500 employees.
> Bailouts for large corporations affected by the pandemic (e.g., airlines, hotels, casinos, cruise line operators, shopping mall operators, etc.).
> Closing borders to all, except U.S. citizens and permanent residents.
> Increased government surveillance and tracking of Americans, residents, and non-residents to monitor the spread of COVID-19.
> Closing immigration courts and detention centers to reduce the spread of COVID-19.
> Publicly funded health insurance ("Medicare for all").
> Expanding access to food assistance programs, such as SNAP and WIC.
> Requiring all non-essential employees to shelter-in-place (i.e., stay in homes and limit travel to only essential trips).
> Closure of all non-essential businesses until further notice.
> Maintaining social distancing of at least 6 feet from other people and refrain from social gatherings of more than 10 people.
> Increased funding for emergency care.

conditions.value:
Participants will be assigned to one of the following two message conditions: humorous, or control condition, as part of a larger 5 condition study (https://osf.io/8hn2g/). Each participant will see a series of 5 messages about COVID-19 randomly sampled from a pool of 15 messages. Each message is created to look like an instagram post that includes a visual message about COVID-19 accompanied by a “post” about the message. Each pair of humorous and control messages have the same image, but the text accompanying the images were manipulated such that the control condition includes only a message about COVID-19, whereas the humorous condition includes the control message in addition to a humorous statement which ridicules those who do not follow social distancing. 

Example: 
Control: Staying home helps stop the spread of #coronavirus
Humorous: Staying home helps stop the spread of #coronavirus. And yet some people will insist on NOT working from home even when their jobs allow it. Why? Cause you miss passing by co-workers on the way to the bathroom?

hypothesis.value:
Primary hypotheses:
H1. Compared to the message control condition, messages using a humorous frame will be associated with stronger perceived norms related to social distancing among people in respondents’ town or city.

H2. Compared to the message control and no message conditions, messages using a humorous frame will be rated as more favorable.

H3: Compared to the message control, messages using a humorous frame will be rated as being more likely to be shared.

Secondary hypotheses and research question:
H4. Relationship between humor and favorability will be stronger for individuals who report higher need for cognition

H5. Relationship between humor and sharing will be stronger for individuals who report higher need for cognition

H6. Compared to the message control condition, messages using a humorous frame will be rated as more socially relevant.

H7. Compared to the message control condition, messages using a humorous frame will be associated with stronger perceived norms related to social distancing among respondents’ close friends and family.

H8. Compared to the message control condition, messages using a humorous frame will be associated with stronger motivation to maintain social distancing.

H9. Compared to the message control condition, messages using a humorous frame will be associated with stronger intentions to engage in social distancing.

H10. Compared to the message control condition, messages using a humorous frame will be associated with stronger perceived social acceptability of engaging in social distancing.

RQ1: Will humorous messages that ridicule people who don’t follow social distancing recommendations when they have the option to, have positive or negative (unintended) consequences in terms of leading to 1) more or less prejudice against vulnerable groups, and 2) greater or lesser support for public policies which protect such vulnerable groups?

Each participant will see a series of 5 messages about COVID-19 randomly sampled from a pool of 15 messages. Each message is created to look like an instagram post that includes a visual message about COVID-19 accompanied by a “post” about the message. Each pair of humorous and control messages have the same image, but the text accompanying the images were manipulated such that the control condition includes only a message about COVID-19, whereas the humorous condition includes the control message in addition to a humorous statement which ridicules those who do not follow social distancing. 

Example: 
Control: Staying home helps stop the spread of #coronavirus
Humorous: Staying home helps stop the spread of #coronavirus. And yet some people will insist on NOT working from home even when their jobs allow it. Why? Cause you miss passing by co-workers on the way to the bathroom?
registration_responses.hypothesis:
Primary hypotheses:
H1. Compared to the message control condition, messages using a humorous frame will be associated with stronger perceived norms related to social distancing among people in respondents’ town or city.

H2. Compared to the message control and no message conditions, messages using a humorous frame will be rated as more favorable.

H3: Compared to the message control, messages using a humorous frame will be rated as being more likely to be shared.

Secondary hypotheses and research question:
H4. Relationship between humor and favorability will be stronger for individuals who report higher need for cognition

H5. Relationship between humor and sharing will be stronger for individuals who report higher need for cognition

H6. Compared to the message control condition, messages using a humorous frame will be rated as more socially relevant.

H7. Compared to the message control condition, messages using a humorous frame will be associated with stronger perceived norms related to social distancing among respondents’ close friends and family.

H8. Compared to the message control condition, messages using a humorous frame will be associated with stronger motivation to maintain social distancing.

H9. Compared to the message control condition, messages using a humorous frame will be associated with stronger intentions to engage in social distancing.

H10. Compared to the message control condition, messages using a humorous frame will be associated with stronger perceived social acceptability of engaging in social distancing.

RQ1: Will humorous messages that ridicule people who don’t follow social distancing recommendations when they have the option to, have positive or negative (unintended) consequences in terms of leading to 1) more or less prejudice against vulnerable groups, and 2) greater or lesser support for public policies which protect such vulnerable groups?

attributes.title: Team Tech
attributes.description: In this study, we will evaluate classroom performance and how it is affected by the amount of non-academic technology use during lectures.

q2.value: maria dates, Taylor Goudy, Mark Gittelson

q4.value: Technology is an essential tool for learning in today’s society which allows students to become easily distracted and affects their academic performance. This hypothesis is directional because we expect to find a decrease in academic performance when there is excessive use of technology in a classroom.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: A proxy server will be used to monitor the browsing activity of participants. Students consented to the monitoring of electronic activity through a digital consent that is displayed when they access the course website. The students were given instructions on how to access the server via email, course website, and demonstration by the researchers at the start of the semester. Students are prompted to sign into the server with their schools issued ID numbers. The use of the ID numbers allows us to track the activity and later overall performance of each student. The proxy server collects the data by tracking which students signed in and every time they switched websites or web apps by tracking HTTP requests. At the completion of the semester, participants were sent a survey via email that asked them the following questions: What was the average amount of minutes used checking social media during lecture?, What was the average amount of minutes used to online shop during lecture?, Did you use your cell phone in class?. The following questions were answered based on the rankings of a Likert scale: Rate how interested you were during the class? Rate how motivated you were during the class? Rate how good or bad your study habits are? Overall, the results were determined based on the academic performance of the participants which was gathered based of cumulative final exam scores.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: For our data collection, we offered course credit to an introduction to sociology class with 345 students. Due to the variety of majors in a general education sociology course, we choose to examine this specific group. Over the course of a semester, students were asked to log into a proxy where researchers were allowed to track the amount of time a student spent on non-academic related websites and applications. We will evaluate a number of different measures and how they relate to the amount of internet usage one participated in. After receiving all the data, we will discard the sample of people who forgot to log out of the proxy once the classroom was over to collect the most accurate data possible.

q13.value: All 354 students will be invited to participate in the study, but we are only expecting at least half to fully participate. After people logged onto the proxy, the sample size would change if we had to discard students who did not log out of the proxy once the lecture is over. Some students chose not to participate as well.

question.value: Our study has been designed to measure the average number of minutes participants spend browsing the Internet during lectures and the average number of HTTP requests that have been made from their computers. The amount of time one spends on the internet is then compared to classroom performance and intelligence to see if there is a significant difference amongst these variables.

To test our hypothesis we will run a Pearson correlation coefficient statistical test between whether the use of the internet during the lecture was non-academic and how much time was used on it. The hierarchical multiple linear regression analysis was used to then find a significant difference between non-academic internet use and student's final exam score which accounts for their academic performance. In this analysis, three other factors were evaluated, intellectual ability, motivation, and interest. Also, the correlations of exams scores amongst the seven different non-academic websites that were used the most were evaluated and tested to see which ones were significant. The significance value used is p less than .05.
